channel.title: music-industry on Daniel Antal, CFA
channel.description: Recent content in music-industry on Daniel Antal, CFA

item.title: Eurpoean Comparison: How Many People Ever Pay For Music, Film or Software
item.description: In our recent private copying reports we compiled European survey data relevant to analysis. In Europe, there is a big difference between the use of electronic entertainment devices in richer and poorer countries. Nevertheless, the real difference is between the number of people who sometimes and who never pay for downloaded music, films and software. In some countries of Europe, less then 10 percent of the population ever pays for the content that is loaded to their computers, smartphones and tablets.

item.title: Slovak Music Industry Report
item.description: The Working with Eurostat data article shows how to work with real-life, current, SNA2010 compatible data from the Eurostat data warehouse. It contains some comparative results between Czechia and Slovakia. The package is in itself is extending the functionality of the eurostat package, and it is released with eurostat in the rOpenGov community.

item.title: Mapping the Croatian Music Industry
item.description: Daniel Antal presented the preliminary findings of the Croatian music industry research in the International Authors’ and Creators’ Conference (Međunarodna autorska kreativna konferencija, #MAKK2015) in Zagreb on 24 November 2015. The presentation was largely based on analysis of various CEEMID databases. The Central European music industry, as shown by processing the data of more than 2000 musicians in the region is even more reliant on live performances than the British music industry.
